column1: There was a missing part of a Dalek, but customer service replaced it. I was fully satisfied...
The central console was a little strange to build. But anyway...I completed it, and now all time and space awaits....
LEGO should not stop with this only set, there is a lot more in the adventures of the Doctor :)

column1:
,TRUE,5,5,4,4,5 Frogan","2015-12-14T20:04:14.183Z","Allons-y - to the store and buy it!","

This is actually my first review on Brickset ever, and English is not my first language, so please excuse my spelling or grammar errors, as I'
column2: m sure some have evaded my proofreading. I&#39
column3: ve recently watched the first few series of the post 2005 Dr. Who series, and I liked them so much that a) I got the Lego set, and b) felt compelled to write this small review. But how about we stop the introduction right here and go to the interesting parts. &ndash

column1: The set comes with the usual Lego Ideas box: Sturdy, opens with a flap, nicely printed. The last aspect is also valid for the instructions. I'
column2: ve not encountered any quality issues, which where common with earlier manuals under the Ideas brand. As always, the instructions come with comments from the designers, and the occasional in-universe information about characters, monsters or gadgets from the Doctor Who series. I&#39
column3: ve not counted them, but I think they are more scarce than in earlier manuals of licensed Ideas sets. Still it makes for a nice addition, and one could say: &ndash
column6: t have missed it for the world&quot

column1: With over 600 parts included, this set has got an (at least for me) acceptable price per piece ratio, especially considering, it is a licensed set. I have to admit that the parts are rather small, so the finished model doesn'
column2: t look like a 600 parts set, but this has become a trend with the more recent Lego sets.

column1: What sticks out is that there are no stickers, even for the Doctor Who specific parts. For me this wouldn'
column2: t be that big of a deal, but I know there are Lego enthusiasts who detest stickers for understandable reasons, so that&#39
column4: ve got lots of other printed tiles, and parts, which would do good service in a spaceship, be it in a cockpit, or an engine room for example.

column1: The colour palette of the parts used is dominated by grey and blue tones, and especially the earth blue parts used for the TARDIS are excellent.

column2: s a specially molded sonic screwdriver, the Doctor&#39
column3: s always handy tool, which has saved his and the life of others numerous times. &ndash
column8: t maim. But I&#39
column9: ll tell you what it does do: It is very good at opening doors.&quot

column3: are composed of three minifigs. All of them have double side printed torsos and printing on the legs. The protagonist is included in not only one, but two forms, namely the 11th and 12th Doctor. Both are rather accurately represented. The 12th Doctor though hasn&#39
column4: t got a double sided head.

column1: The companion is Clara Oswald, the - to date - longest-serving companion in the new show. She too looks good, has a double sided head, one side shows a scared face, the other a neutral one. It might have been nice, if other companions would'
A Weeping Angel serves as foe. It has an excellent double sided head, one side showing a neutral expression, and the other with fletched teeth.

column2: ll also mention the Daleks here. The are brick-built, and good imaginations of their TV counterparts. The printed dome is fantastic. It would have been nice, if the lights would protrude like on TV. A note about the colour scheme: In the series it looks rather bronze metallic, the Lego version is in brown tones. While not perfect, it is okay. What is strange is that this version of the Daleks was most prominent during the 9th and 10th Doctors&#39
column3: tenures. Nonetheless, they have but one goal. &ndash

column1: Building starts, as usual with the minifigures. Next is the TARDIS control room. The highlight is, of course the centerpiece, the control console, which makes for an interesting build. Next are the 2 Daleks.Finally, the one piece, most of the Doctor Who fans where waiting for, the police box concludes the build.

While there are a few steps one could consider repetitive, they are not very long. The methods used are not that complicated or advanced, and they do their best do make for an authentic representation. &ndash

My main critique with this set are related to the opening mechanism of the TARDIS. First you have to remove the roof, to connect the box with the interior. And second, there is no way to enter the police box from the front, which would have added to the play value for kids. From an AFOL'
column2: s perspective though, this is neglectable.

s perspective, one could consider this set a paradox for the following reasons. The control room is from series 7 - till the 12th Doctor renovates it it in series 8. The Doctors are from series 5 to (at least) 9. Clara accompanied the Doctor during series 7 to 9. So this side of the model depicts a rather short timespan between series 7 and 8. What doesn&#39
column3: t fit in this timeline though are the Doctor&#39
column4: s opponents: The Daleks colour scheme doesn&#39
column5: t fit, since it changed in series 5 to a more colorful one, and the Weeping Angel have had only cameo appearances in the later series, they were more prominently in series 5.

column1: So how does the TARDIS hold up after all? Great, I especially like that the stairway leaves the possibility to extend it'
column2: s interior to rooms and areas seen ore mentioned in the TV series. You know, like a library or a swimming pool. &ndash

column1: Does the mentioned paradox annoy me? Well, actually no, for me it is a good compromise. Should it annoy Whovians? Probably a little, but does it really matter so much. In fact, as there are multiple Doctor'
column2: s and foes, the set is pretty versatile and makes for a good play value. One could even think of their own Christmas special and have the two Doctor&#39
column3: s work together. And if, like me, you&#39
column4: ve got no intentions to play with the set, it is an excellent display piece, even if you have to display the police box alone. Personally I would have liked it, if the 10th Doctor was present, so I could say &quot
column7: ll get his own set in the future. The license definitely has got enough material to earn his own line, let&#39
column8: s see, if Lego further publishes DW sets.

column2: ve enjoyed my review, and concerning my final verdict: Run to the store and get one, it&#39

column1:
,TRUE,5,5,5,5,4 PeteM","2015-12-24T19:24:24.17Z","A Madman With A Box","

I honestly can&rsquo
column2: t remember which entered my life first &ndash
column3: Lego or Doctor Who. One of my first and clearest childhood memories is building track for #7720 across the living room floor, while on television a giant polystyrene statue fell on Colin Baker. Both became icons of my childhood that I&rsquo
column4: ve stubbornly refused to let go of, despite varying lengths of time away from each, so the announcement from Lego Ideas that they would finally be drawn together in an official set succeeded in sending two of my fan genes into overdrive at the same time.

column1: The box is the same high-quality flip top affair common to both the Ideas and Architecture ranges and is filled to brim with unmarked bags containing the 623 pieces. The instructions are a fairly weighty tome laid flat at the bottom, with the 100-odd steps required for the model well laid out, and clear and simple to follow, easily satisfying the 10+ rating on the box. As with all Ideas sets there are also a few &lsquo
column4: in this case some background on the programme, characters and the TARDIS, as well as some words from the original designer Andrew Clarke and the Lego designers tasked with translating the submission into an actual set (one of whom is serendipitously related to Doctor No. 8 Paul McGann). There are also numerous bite sized facts about the show and model spread throughout the booklet.

column2: For some people, small beautiful things are&nbsp

column1: It is no surprise that the parts that immediately draw the eye are those in the rather lovely shade of deep blue that make up the TARDIS exterior. These are mostly plate or tile based, as well as the blue window frames and matching solid panes.
There is an absolute riot of printed pieces, most noticeably those used for the TARDIS exterior. The print for each &lsquo
column3: sign is split across two 1x3 tiles (for reasons that become clear later), and there is also printing on a total of ten of the window pieces, eight with the window panes design, one with the &lsquo
column5: sign and one with the St John&rsquo
column6: s Ambulance crest. There are also two 2x2 round tiles printed with a &lsquo
column8: design (lights and other detailing) as well as numerous computer panel type prints, some of which are generic while others are unique to this set.

column1: The only other parts which were new to me were both transparent &ndash
column2: a neck brace with two studs facing outwards, and a single 1x1 tile with a spike on it, both of which are new to sets in 2015. The remaining pieces mainly consist of a wide variety of standard plates and bricks in shades of grey which make up the console room.

column1: The Twelfth Doctor is wearing his immediate post-regeneration outfit from the beginning of his debut story (shed less than ten minutes into his first episode and never seen again), a sort of hairy purple suit inherited from the final days of the Eleventh Doctor. Maybe a tad brighter than what was seen on screen, this is none the less an excellent representation of the costume. The new hairpiece is a fairly good match for Peter Capaldi&rsquo
column2: s Season 8 style and is currently unique to only Doctor Who sets.

column1: The Eleventh Doctor is resplendent in his &lsquo
column4: s first few seasons, namely the tweed suit and bow tie. The printing from the jacket continues onto the top of the legs, though it isn&rsquo
column5: t a great colour match between the two elements, possibly due to the legs having a brown background colour which may have dimmed the lighter tan printing.

column1: Clara is perhaps the most generic of the selection, though does get some well-done dual-moulded legs with a tartan miniskirt and black jacket, as per her appearance in Matt Smith&rsquo

The Weeping Angel is a fantastic representation of one of the scariest monsters in Doctor Who history, the killer statues that remain stationary while observed . . . until you blink . . . It is complete with dual-sided face, one calm serene expression and the other a terrifying jagged-toothed scream representing the Angel as it attacks it&rsquo
column2: s prey. The torso and sloped &lsquo
column4: brick are both printed with a stone-carved drapes design and the wings are mounted onto the back via the transparent neck brace and two clips.

column1: The build starts with fairly simple plate and inverted wedge brick arrangements forming the initial &ldquo
column3: and decking section of the console room. The time rotor is sub-build all of its own, and consists of numerous elements threaded onto two Technic rods, starting with a large webbed radar disk on top. There is a little repetition when it comes to creating the six sides of the central console as they are all based on an identical base build &ndash
column4: two wedge plates combined at 90 degrees to each other, with a 1x2 clip at the back &ndash
column5: but all feature a slightly different build on the main &lsquo
column7: . These clip onto a neat little construction at the base of the time rotor build, where two stacked fly wheels hold six pneumatic hose connectors evenly spaced around the outside, cleverly creating six connection points all facing in different directions. The two sets of angled railings around the outside of the main walkway look straightforward &ndash
column8: just three light grey bars joined together by angled Technic connectors &ndash
column9: but they are quite difficult to get in place evenly, despite the fact that the clips that attach it to the floor section are able to both revolve and flex up and down. Much easier are the wide flat computer consoles constructed from a few wedge plates and more printed tiles, which just clip onto the railings.

column1: The Daleks are deceptively simple, with a core of stacked plates and SNOT bricks, onto which wedge plates are mounted on either side.
column2: The distinctive sloped shape of the base is approximated by 1x2 plates front and back that are angled on clips. Above this a 1x2 jumper plate allows transition to 2x2 round plates, with the eyestalk piece sandwiched between these and the printed round tile on top.
the TARDIS! Starting with an odd 7x7 base, the outer edges are tiled all the way around and the base is mostly in-filled with silver 1x2 grilles. Gaps are left for two 2x2 plates, a&nbsp
column3: cunning way to create a half stud offset without using any &lsquo
column5: elements by adding plates to the layer above. Two of the sides hinge half way down their length, sliding over the grill and plate base to create a square 6x6 area when closed. The panelled walls are simply a series of window frames with the correct blank or printed panes inserted at the right level. These are joined at each corner by 1x1 plates and 1x1 bricks with a stud on the side, stacked to the same height as the walls and with 1x8 dark blue tiles attached vertically to provide the offset pillar detailing. Each of the Police Box signs are mounted onto one side of a corner plate, with the two on the sides affixed to hinges to allow them to swivel upwards. The roof is constructed simply from basic plates and tiles, held in place by two 2x2 jumper plates on the main body which allow for easy removal.

column3: s no point being grown-up if you can&#39

column2: ve read this far, it will come as no surprise that I think the completed model is just fantastic. Both parts of the set look great, and the integration of the two is genius, with the TARDIS folding open and the console room lining up with the inside &ndash
column4: bigger on the inside than the outside&rdquo
column5: feature. In order to allow the box to open, the logic behind having the Police Box signs printed across two tiles is revealed as they are mounted on hinges which rotate 90 degrees skywards and the hinges in the main structure can then fold outwards. This also means that the actual doors don&rsquo
column6: t open, but again, this trade-off for scale and functionality is hardly a problem for an imaginative child, and is perfectly fine for adult collectors too!

column1: Looking at this as a fan there are of course a number of things that aren&rsquo
column2: t entirely faithful to the source material &ndash
column3: there should be an additional row of panels on the exterior of the TARDIS (three rows, then the windows) and the arrangement of the concentric rings at the top of the time rotor hasn&rsquo
column4: t quite been captured, but these are minor quibbles born of obsession,&nbsp
column6: t required when the results are this good. While the TARDIS isn&#39
column7: t perfectly scaled to the minifigs, it is as near a perfect representation of the prop as can be made with Lego &ndash
column8: and it&#39
column9: s worth bearing in mind that not even the show has been consistent with the exterior over the past 52 years!&nbsp

column1: The arms holding the railings around the console area provide a somewhat rickety solution to that feature and are difficult to make symmetrical, but look great when in place.
column2: I like that each face of the console has its own discrete design, with the type and combination of elements placed on the 2x2 space on the top varying greatly. These are a combination of printed tiles and &lsquo
column4: , the best of the latter being the imaginative use of a zip line handle piece as a large old fashioned switch, which is entirely faithful to the prop on the show. Fitting with the established &lsquo
column6: , the colour theme of the console clearly reflects the final series of the Eleventh Doctor, but to change it to the vivid bright orange of Series 9 should take nothing more than a few carefully selected orders at the third party part seller of your choice (though not necessarily cheap!). The console room construction is surprisingly solid and can even be picked up and flow around (gently!) from the top of the time rotor without it all falling to bits.

column1: The Daleks are as good as could be hoped for and somehow look far better in person than they do in any photos, so long as you don&rsquo
column2: t look at them direct head on where the odd use of a 1x2 jumper plate makes the mid-section far too thin. They don&rsquo
column5: s iconic design exactly due to scale, but I&rsquo
column6: d far rather this brick-build solution than the use of any specialised pieces. The advantage of living in the internet ages is that there are numerous other solutions out there if this one doesn&rsquo

column2: ve been trying to recreate the TARDIS in Lego form for the past thirty years (OK, so there was an 15 year gap while I sorted out dating, marriage and a mortgage, but still...) so to finally have an official version in my hands is a long held dream come true. I can only hope that it is popular enough for Lego to consider a larger range, though if that doesn&rsquo
column3: t materialise then this will still remain as a wonderful standalone set, achieving the rare hat trick of being an interesting build, a good display piece and high in play value. Exceeding my expectations in every area, this was well worth the wait and I wouldn&rsquo
column4: t hesitate to call it my set of the year.

column2: A thing that looks like a police box, standing in a junkyard, it can move anywhere in time and space?&rdquo

column1:
,TRUE,5,5,5,4,5 Professor_X","2016-01-20T19:19:32.467Z","""It's Bigger on the Inside""","

Doctor Who had been something I sort of new about from 1 or 2 friends and I always used to think of it as "
column2: that British sci-fi thing that everyone&#39
column4: I started to pay a bit more attention however with all the LEGO Ideas hype about it, and when it reached 10,000 supporters and was eventually announced as the next Ideas product&nbsp
column6: t particularly surprised(SO many LEGO fans are British!, I mean, even Huw and Captain Rex!). But when I saw the set images...man...I knew I had to have it. Reading Huw&#39
column7: s review only made me more mad that I couldn&#39
column8: t have RIGHT now and of course LEGO was irritating enough to release it in December when I&#39
column9: m running around spending all my money on Christmas presents(just kidding by the way, I do like giving presents). Naturally, I put this on my own Christmas list, and when I unwrapped it I couldn&#39
column10: t wait to finally build it! So, is this set a winner whether you&#39
column11: re a Doctor Who fan or not? Or is it another over glorified collector&#39
column12: s item that will only appeal to a certain niche. Read on to find out...

column1: Lego Ideas and/or CUUSOO sets are such good quality products. The box is reusable and can be opened and closed for storage, which I think is a nice touch. The instructions feature short descriptions of the show, the characters, and even the set designers, along with little explanations and facts about the different things you'
column2: re building along the way. The whole thing just screams quality, though the only thing that detracts from this is that since the bags aren&#39
column3: t numbered, you have to dump out all the contents at once and all those pieces are kind of hard to sift through(this model is DENSE). Other than that little complaint though, building this set is a great experience and its nice to know you can get sets of this quality without having to fork over hundreds of dollars.

column1: (Peter Capaldi): The 12th and current Doctor, while still recognizable, is a bit of a strange variation. While I'
column2: m not a Doctor Who fan, I have done my research and have concluded that its very likely this whole set is loosely based on the episode, &quot
column4: This episode is the first appearance of the 12th Doctor, and this appears to be the outfit he wears in that episode. Nonetheless, I really like the simplicity of this minifigures design: A purple coat over a navy vest over a white shirt, with a gold pocket watch visible as well. While I think that Dark red might have been a better color choice for the coat, the outfit still looks like something the Doctor would wear and so it doesn&#39
column5: t bother me much. Oddly this minifigure doesn&#39
column6: t have a reversible head, so the stern expression is the only one you&#39
column7: re going to get. the Doctor&#39
column8: s Hairpiece seemed at first to have been made especially for him, but after looking at the Peter Venkman minifigure from Ghostbusters, I assume that the hair was first made for him, then somebody thought it would look good on this minifigure and the Doctor happened to get produced first. While this hairpiece

column1: in light grey would probably have been a better choice, I like that the Doctor has a more unique hairpiece to set him apart and overall I really like this version of him.

Being some what of a fanatical minifigure collector, its very rare that I say that a minifgure is frighteningly accurate to the source material. This is one of the few times I must confess that this minifigure'
column3: s all perfect: The jacket with a striped shirt and bow-tie, the expression on his face, that hair! It all looks so good! The only flaw is that the continued printing of the Doctor&#39
column4: s jacket onto his legs is pretty faded, but this minifigure is so perfect I think I can live with that. His face has two expressions: serious with the hint of a smile, and out right laughing. The Doctor is armed with his trademark Sonic Screwdriver(an extra is included if you want to arm the 12th Doctor as well), and of course a fez. This minifigure is perfect, just perfect! If you&#39
column5: re a minifigure collector this is one you should own.

column1: Further proving my theory about this set being based on "
column3: , Clara Oswald is dressed in the outfit she wears in that episode. The black sweater and red skirt look very good together and the detail on her legs is especially impressive. Her legs are dual molded(top half black and bottom half red), and speaking as one who hadn&#39
column4: t seen this before up close I&#39
column5: m really glad LEGO is using that technique more. Clara&#39
column6: s face is fairly generic, one side has a smiling expression and the other side has a confused look. Her hair is also pretty commonplace, reddish-brown draping over the right shoulder, and in my opinion is a very overused piece. while her head and hairpieces aren&#39
column7: t as great as the other minifigures, I still think that Clara is recognizable enough to fit in with the others.

column1: When I first heard of Weeping Angels I didn'
column2: t quite understand them, but having done some research I began to really love the concept. This Minifigure, like the 11th Doctor, is extremely accurate as well. Her simple dress is printed accurately and while her wings should probably be in a folded position, I happen to be a fan of these&nbsp
column3: wings and was glad to get&nbsp
column4: some. They are connected to her back via clips which are attached to the new see-through 2x1 neck bracket piece introduced in the DC Comics Super Heroes line. One side of her head is calm and serene, just like a normal statue should be, on the other side however...BAM! Possibly the most Frightening head in minifigure history contorted into a evil scream! The Weeping Angel&#39
column5: s hair piece is typically used for queen minifigures, and this is its first appearance in light grey which I believe will be useful for making minifigures of a certain female monarch. My only complaint about this minifigure...We don&#39
column6: t get more! I think that this minifigures amazing detail will demand a high price from the secondary market and it&#39
column7: s definitely become a favorite of mine

column1: The TARDIS Console room, while not the most prolific version, is instantly recognizable. Another piece of evidence that this set is inspired by the episode, "
column3: , this Console Room appears to based on the version appearing during the late 11th doctor-early 12th doctor era, which I think is a good version to base it on considering that this set features both. If you love control panels like I do, this set is a dream come true. Over ten 2x1 control panel pieces are used all over as well several transparent studs, an exclusive printed 2x4 round plate, and 2 printed clip on square pieces representing computer screens. While The console area itself is a bit bulky, it&#39
column4: s variety of controls look amazing and while the whole thing is designed very simply it&#39
column5: s a very excellent representation of the source material. The room itself is simple enough, with some large bar pieces representing the railing mounted with more control panels, some simple stairs attached to a ladder piece, and a small platform attached to a Technique pin that can lock into the TARDIS Model. The console room, on the whole, is excellent, providing a stunning display model as well as something that&#39

column2: s most prominent antagonists, and were of course an essential for this set. Most likely based on the Daleks currently seen on screen, these Daleks are mostly dark tan in color with a little bit of gold thrown in around the top. While not perfect, I think the Daleks are recreated well and are pretty consistent wit the source material. While they appear to be simple builds, they actually include some interesting parts such as the new see-through stud with nipple piece and their new printed dome pieces. exposed studs around their bottoms of course create the texturing of the Daleks shells very accurately and their respective suction-like arms and weapon arms are recreated pretty well. I really like how the head is constructe, putting to good use&nbsp
column3: the 2x1 round plate with a hole in the center attached to the dome piece via a nunchuk handle. While I&#39
column4: m a bigger fan of the LEGO Dimensions Daleks, these are still accurate representations that I sure will be sought after by Doctor Who fans for army building(I mean, who doesn&#39
column5: t want an army of LEGO Daleks. EXTERMINATE!).

column1: The most legendary phone booth in the world, The TARDIS has become a huge sci-fi icon as well as something several builders have tried to recreate. Now, at long last, LEGO has made one in a set and it couldn&#39
column3: re a fan of dark blue, this model is now your best friend. The amount of useful dark blue pieces here is&nbsp
column4: amazing, from your basic plates, to your printed pieces, to even small windows and window panes used to recreate the TARDIS&#39
column5: outside paneling. One of the coolest things about this model is its use in creating the &quot
column7: of the TARDIS by allowing it to hook up to the console room. By removing the roof, flipping the top panels up on the left and right sides, and then opening up the back a small interior can be seen, which includes details like the white mirror image of the door and the blue and orange circular lights which can be seen all around the interior in the show. One then only needs to hook up the TARDIS via a Technique pin to the rest of the set, and it recreates a full out, believable TARDIS interior. This model isn&#39
column8: t perfect, mostly because of the fact that its humongous&nbsp
column9: compared to &nbsp
column10: minifigures, but other than that I think its one of the most accurate LEGO models I&#39
column11: ve seen in a set in a long time and its ability to attach to the console room is a great feature

column3: m not even a Doctor Who fan, and now I&#39
column4: m really interested in the show! This set is such a high quality product, from the minifigures, to the amount of printed pieces, to even the quality of the building instructions. While some may look at this and think it&#39
column5: s a little small for a $69.99 CA/$59.99 US set, not only is a surprisingly dense but you&#39
column6: re paying for a set that&#39
column7: s been made with all kinds of little details to delight hardcore LEGO fans and Doctor Who fans alike. If you love Doctor Who, get this set. If you love LEGO, get this set. If you have $70 that you don&#39
column8: t know how to spend, get this set. Trust me, you won&#39
column9: t be disappointed (I may just have to go and binge watch some Doctor Who on Netflix!)

,TRUE,5,4,5,3,5 HdmLegoLad","2016-04-05T02:58:02.597Z","The Doctor Is In!","

Good Evening,Whovians and Lego fans alike! Let us rejoice in the combination of Lego and Doctor Who! This is the Lego set made by Whovians for Whovians! When Andrew Clark Introduced this set on Lego Ideas I knew this was the set I wanted! Months later,I got
column2: it as a gift from my aunt and I built it in an hour and 45&nbsp
column3: minutes.Without further ado,let us travel into the blue box that&#39

column1: On the box there is a wonderful image of the set itself and in the corner there is an image of the Eleventh Doctor and Weeping Angel minifigures,and in the center is the set itself,with a grouchy looking Twelfth Doctor played the wonderful Peter Capaldi,with an unsure Clara running in the TARDIS
column4: are also seen looking menacingly at the duo! The back offers the same details as the front,and shows info on Lego Ideas.Com, The instructions as all others are easy to follow and even featured bios on the characters and the Police Box itself! It also has a bio on Andrew Clark himself,and an ad for the Lego Dimensions Level Pack also available with the Twelfth Doctor,K-9 and the Police Box.&nbsp

column1: We get lots of printed parts,such as the window panes,Police box signage,St Johns ambulance badge,"
column3: door sign,and the doors itself with the panes and lock on the door.We also get the printed pieces to resemble the bits and bobs of the console,and printed parts for the Dalek&#39

column1: The Minifigures include the Twelfth Doctor in Elevens clothes,Clara in her clothing from "
column4: clothes with the trademark bow tie and tweed coat,A menacing Weeping Angel with giant wings attached to a special clip on the back,and two brick built Daleks,with the exterminator ray and the plunger.For accessories The Doctors come with Sonic Screwdrivers and two are included,as in series 8-9,the Twelfth Doctor uses Elevens after he regenerates.

column1: Building the set may be a bit challenging for younger builders,as the console can be a bit repetitive,and the bags aren'
column2: t numbered,which may be a bit challenging,so color coding the bricks may be easier.However,for older fans building may be faster,and it should take some 1 1/2 to 2 hours.The instructions were very clear,and it was a joy building my very own time machine,I just wish the chameleon circuit would be fixed!

column1: The complete model is gorgeous and was so much fun to build! Although I love applying the stickers,the printed pieces are a lot more convenient.Overall there'
column2: s lots of detail,I think it&#39
column3: s cool how the the Police Box itself can actually open,and it could be clipped in to make the TARDIS&nbsp
column4: bigger on the inside! I also like how the lever on the console can actually be pulled down to feel as though the TARDIS&nbsp
column5: is powering up! The only complaint I have is that I wish there were alternative bricks,so you can either make the Elevenths TARDIS&nbsp
column6: from season 7B,or orange blades and clear bricks to make the Twelfths TARDIS.

column1: In the end,I feel this set is perfect for any Whovian

column1: ,TRUE,5,5,4,3,5 Odeinoichus","2017-05-20T16:55:41.48Z","Time and Relative Dimensions in Space...EXTERMINATE!","
column8: >Set #21304 Doctor Who:
column9: ><span style=""color: rgb(68, 68, 68)
column13: > Fans of British Science Fiction staples rejoice, The Doctor is in, and in this particular case this set is most impressive for Ideas, despite being a bit awkward for keeping on the shelf. I shall do my best to explain this set in a review setting, however I must admit that while I know some of Doctor Who as I have enjoyed watching the series for a while now, I don&rsquo
column14: t know every nuance about the Tardis&rsquo
column15: control centre. So forgive me if I don&rsquo
column16: t use proper names for things.

column8: >Box: Like with other Ideas sets this particular box design features an impressive image of the set on the front and back with all the features being featured. It&rsquo
column9: s also a very high-end style of box, something worth keeping for fans. The Tardis is everywhere, from logos to artwork, you know right off the bat what is supposed to be there.

column8: >Instructions: A thick looking manual this one features pages with write-ups on the designers, the fictional setting of the Doctor&rsquo
column9: s world and of course some fun trivia and facts scattered through the build steps. It&rsquo
column10: s a really impressive design for LEGO Manuals with these LEGO Ideas sets. You&rsquo
column11: ll also find some cross-promotional images for the LEGO Dimensions Level Pack and the Birds Ideas set in the back.

column8: >This set isn&rsquo
column9: t designed for MOC fans, it&rsquo
column10: s designed for fans of Doctor Who, however this set features a few interesting pieces, the printed elements are all specific for the Tardis&rsquo
column11: windows and doors and control panels, while the Dalek&rsquo
column12: s introduced a new piece in this set for their eye stalks, which is really useful and has proven itself twice over a few years after it was introduced.

column8: >Clara Oswald: Not everybodies favorite companion, she&rsquo
column9: s an acquired taste. But as a Minifigure she looks cute, with her dual-molded legs and fun skirt print and her tight looking black sweater. She too comes with a dual-sided facial print with a happy and angry expression, her hair has been seen many times before though and she isn&rsquo

column8: >All-in-all the Impossible Girl is very fun. And a suitable addition to the set. Can we please get a Companions of the Doctor set though LEGO? I know I can&rsquo
column9: t be the only one who wants to see Barbara or Amy or any number of other fun and iconic characters from the Doctor Who universe.

column8: >Dalek: EXTERMINATE! EXTERMINATE! Two of the iconic enemies of the Doctor are built-up with bricks in this set, there are printed head plates, however that&rsquo
column9: s the only printed piece. The rest is built by bricks and tiles and two new eyestalk pieces and they both look great.

column8: >Some may argue that they aren&rsquo
column9: t Minifigures, or that they aren&rsquo
column10: t perfect, but they are excellent mini-models and stand out as some of the biggest draws for the set.

column8: >Doctor Twelve: Mister Fez&rsquo
column9: s are cool himself, this Doctor represents Matt Smith in his more iconic outfit. The print detailing is just as good here as it is on his Thirteenth counterpart. He gets his own sonic as well, due to the fact that you get two in the set, and he also has a Fez.

column8: >I&rsquo
column9: m afraid though that wearing the Fez just looks terrible, mostly because this Doctor has a dual-sided face with two different expressions. Happy Smith, Serious Smith, also since the hair piece isn&rsquo
column10: t underneath the Fez he comes off as an odd two-faced bald Janus or something. But he&rsquo
column11: s still an excellent addition for the set and at least you have two Doctor&rsquo

column8: >Doctor Thirteen: This version of the Doctor represents him just after regeneration. He&rsquo
column9: s dressed in Matt Smith&rsquo
column10: s last outfit and so you can swap heads to recreate the iconic scene in play sessions or brick films. Holding the new sonic accessory and featuring a unique new hair piece Doctor Thirteen looks brilliant, the only downside is his lack of a double-sided face. He has only one expression, but his attack eyebrows are completely intact for this little Minifigure.

column8: >Weeping Angel: This is one of the first LEGO Minifigures that I think represents a truly creepy and terrifying creature. We&rsquo
column9: ve had monsters before in other Themes, but the Weeping Angel is one of the most terrifying creatures that Doctor has had to face in his many travels and this Minifigure captures that quite perfectly.

column8: >Don&rsquo
column9: t blink or you&rsquo
column10: ll be trapped in time and used to feed the beast. It&rsquo
column11: s so cute too for a little abomination of horror. The print is excellent and the parts are perfect, the double-sided face reveals a horrible secret though for all your other Minifigures. She&rsquo
column12: s ready to devour their entire lifespan in time. The only downside is you only get one, LEGO needs to make some Weeping Angel battle packs somehow.

column8: >Control Area: This is definitely a 10+ set, younger builders might struggle with some of the steps in this build, especially as you build the central control nexus of the Tardis&rsquo
column9: time circuits. Even I, an AFOL, had some difficulty in getting the top satellite dish pieces to line up and attach properly without applying too much force. The control consoles attached to the rods on either side of the central area were somewhat annoying to line up properly as well, since LEGO did not introduce the new flexible rods yet in models of this type.

column8: >The stairs like to move a lot as well, for a small three step ladder it is a bit finicky. And I recall several moments of fidgeting to get the floor panels for the upper control section to attack to the lower portion of the under carriage. It&rsquo
column9: s still quite satisfying once you complete the model though, however I feel the true charm of this set is when you&rsquo

column8: >Tardis: This is wholly satisfying. It may not be 100% to scale, but it works with Minifigures and the build, while slightly repetitive in certain steps due to the nature of building a rectangular box resembling an old British Police Public Call Box, it&rsquo
column9: s so much fun. A lot more fun than when you had to build the interior of the control area.

column8: >Every step adds to the overall model and by the time you complete the upper roof section and seal it off you marvel at the design and the SNOT techniques in use to minimize the presence of standard LEGO studs on the outside for attaching elements. I found myself having a lot more fun with this model than the larger one, perhaps because of the fact that it was so much simpler to deal with and follow along.

>The Tardis: This model captures the likeness of the titular Time and Relative Dimensions in Space vehicle which our good friend The Doctor stole to leap into time and space. The printed detailing is superbly executed and the model can even open up on hinges so you can fit a Minifigure inside. It doesn&rsquo
column9: t open the doors as you would expect, you need to pop the top off and flip some hinged portions to allow the Tardis to open. However I do think it&rsquo

column8: >As a bonus it can be left open and attached via Technic axle pin to the central control nexus of the Tardis. This model is perfect for play as well, not just a display piece, but an excellent LEGO model to use in Brickfilms, or just have fun spinning around and around through the time vortex as The Doctor and Companion rush off into adventure after adventure.

>The Interior of the Tardis: This is basically the central control area for the Tardis as seen with the Eleventh and Twelfth Doctors (or Twelve and Thirteen if you prefer conventional accuracy with your numbering) and it is a semi-decent display model. I honestly don&rsquo
column9: t know if it&rsquo
column10: s the best that could be add, but I do know that it includes all printed elements, no stickers at all.

column8: >Some of this build, from what I can recall, was very problematic in getting together. The placement of the railings on the side, the top of the central control shaft and some of the finicky bits to affix the consoles in their proper placement lead to a true 10+ recommendation for the building here. That being said the model itself is quite nice, it works well sitting on any shelf for the interior of the command area of the Tardis. It can fit three Minifigures without issue and attaches to the Tardis model as noted before so that you can display everything as one continuous piece.

>I do wish the attachment for the steps was handled more securely, the simple ladder/scaffolding piece used for the base of the tree floating steps leading down further into the Tardis is very lose. If you find yourself moving the model around a lot to dust and alter how it is displayed or where it is displayed this piece will start to flop around quite easily and become very unstable.
>The printed tiles and plates however are a real treat, many of them are re-used from Star Wars or similarly based space/fantasy type sets, but the unique elements for Doctor Who are great.
>This is a very impressive set, much like the DeLorean Time Machine and the Ecto-1 this set stands out to me as one of the more iconic offerings from Ideas. It&rsquo
column9: s certainly up there as one of the better offerings, if slightly flawed in some of the build techniques. I love the Tardis and the Minifigures and the interior control area is a suitable display base for a decent Doctor Who display. I would hope that LEGO might see more value in giving us further sets from this Theme similar to how Minecraft took off, but that remains to be seen. There aren&rsquo
column10: t too many things iconic enough to be built in LEGO and most of what fans want are Minifigures of all the Doctors and their Companions/Allies with a few more Enemies.

column8: >I would recommend tracking this down if you missed it originally as it is a must own set for Who fans of all ages and compliments the LEGO Dimensions sets very nicely. An excellent set, strongly recommended.

If you are a fan of the British television series Dr. Who, you will love the set.
You get the disguised TARDIS a.k.a. Blue box a.k.a. Policebox, that had been all over England as the show started 50 years ago. It had then a longer pause and was re-ignited about 10 years ago.
You get also a version of the &bdquo
column4: that is bigger on the inside.

column1: Also you get the archenemies Daleks and weeping angels, so don&rsquo
Two doctors and one companion is included, I personally like Amy more, but this is Clara.
The set got all the important parts of the show, but as a matter of fact, it is more something you put at display. You can play also with it, but it for sure aims more at the adult Fans of the show.
If Lego used the correct hue of blue for the TARDIS, you will have a hard time to get the parts. Also the tiles have some nice details on, so also hard to find parts.
For the fans of the show it is a must have!
